page.title: 05HEATH LAND
page.content: Dartford Heath is an area of general heathland existing as part of the Green Belt. The underlying sands and pebbles give rise to an infertile soil unsuitable for farming. The southern boundary of the heath is now marked by the A.2 (T). From here and adjoining roads, views of the heath can be seen. Bracken, grass and gorse cover the area and give rise in dry weather to fire risk. When the gorse is in bloom the heath is ablaze with colour. Many birds can be seen in the area especially the Magpie which can be seen strutting along the roads and paths which criss-cross the heath. This was the home of the Dartford Warbler, now no longer seen in this area. Part of the heath has been made into an 18 hole golf course. The club house of Dartford golf club being easily accessable from the roads on the heath.
